bibl.title: Notes on Reed and Carroll, by [Charles S. White] to [Philip Showalter Hench], [January 10, 1942]

div1.p: [White] describes Reed and Carroll, both of whom he knew personally, and describes Reed's appendix operation. [White] administered the anesthetic for the operation.

div1.head: Notes on Reed and Carroll, by [Charles S. White] to [Philip Showalter Hench], [January 10, 1942]
div1.p:
Dr. Walter Reed was Professor of Bacteriology in the Columbian
University (now George Washington University) from 1895 to 1901.
He was Professor of Bacteriology and Pathology from 1901 to the date
of his death.

In 1897-98, I was a student in this medical school and attended
Dr. Reed's lectures and laboratory course.

Dr. Reed was never late in meeting the students. His attire was
conservative but immaculate. While addressing the class he walking
slowly before the students and spoke with great clarity, precision
and force. His lectures were models in English and his scientific data
were assembled in perfect order. There was nothing of the dramatic in
his speech or manner, but he impressed one with his earnestness,
thoroughness, and mastery of his subject.

He was
never in
uniform.
c. s. w.

After graduation I spent several hours three times each week as
a demonstrator in Dr. Reed's laboratory in the medical school.
Dr. James Carroll was assistant professor and did most of the routine
work with several helpers, but rarely or never took Dr. Reed's place
as a lecturer. Dr. Carroll was just a swell laboratory man and lacked
the personality, culture and background of Dr. Reed. To be frank,
Dr. Carroll was a bit crude and had a vocabulary of profanity that
would be the envy of any sailor. Withal, he was kind, industrious, and
always willing to lend a hand to any student in difficulty with his
slides.

My recollection of Dr. Reed's operation is about as follows:
Dr. J. Wesley Bovee, a classmate of Dr. Borden, requested me the day
before the operation to give the Nitrous-Oxide Ether anesthesia.
I had been Bovee's interne two years and had given many anesthetics for
him, - consequently the call.

I went to the Washington Barracks, to the Army Hospital, the morning
of the operation and was taken to the operating room where I saw Dr. Reed
on the table. I assembled my apparatus - the Bennett inhaler and the tank
of Nitrous Oxide and ether can - and asked Dr. Reed if he had any false teeth.
He answered with a decisive “No”.

We had hospital stewards all about, Major Borden and several spectators,
one of whom was Major Kean, I believe, and probably Dr. Bovee. Dr. Reed
took the anesthetic quietly and well. The appendix was gangrenous and
what impressed me was the necrotic condition of the cecum, in which was a
gaping hole as the appendix was removed. I recall with vividness that
efforts to close the opening was met with little success, as each time
a suture was placed in the wall, the catgut would tear out when the edges
of the opening in the colon were approximated. This was repeated several
times with indifferent results.

I never saw Dr. Reed later, but his condition was reported by Major
Borden daily and it was evident that he died from peritonitis in about
six days after the operation.
